Graphical abstract Supported Ga catalysts have been widely studied for propane dehydrogenation (PDH). In this study, Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were evaluated for PDH. The propylene selectivity decreased with increasing propane conversion. It is generally thought that propylene and light gas by-products occur from chemisorbed propane and are, therefore, primary products. By extrapolating the product selectivities to zero per cent propane conversion, the initial propylene selectivity was near 100% and is a primary product. The light gas selectivities, however, are near 0% indicating that these are secondary products. The direct reaction of propylene produced the same light gas products, e.g., methane, ethylene, propane, butenes and pentenes, observed for PDH and confirmed that these occur by an independent reaction of propylene. Thus, while the intrinsic PDH propylene selectivity is high, these secondary propylene reactions lower the selectivity, especially, at higher conversions and higher partial pressures. Keywords Ga propane dehydrogenation Single site gallium catalyst Propylene secondary reactions during propane dehydrogenation Gallium on alumina structure Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propylene is the second largest petrochemical and is used for the production of a variety of products including polypropylene, propylene oxide, acrolein, acrylonitrile, fuels, etc [1]. Propylene is primarily produced by steam cracking of naphtha and fluid catalytic cracking. With the recent large increase in availability of natural gas liquids from horizontal drilling and fracking of shale formations, in the US the naphtha feed to steam crackers has largely been replaced by ethane for production of ethylene. Ethane steam cracking, however, produces little propylene; thus, there is increasing interest in on-purpose production of propylene by propane dehydrogenation (PDH). For PDH, the two most common commercial technologies are UOP’s Oleflex [2] and the Lummus-Clariant’s Catofin processes. The former uses a Pt-Sn alloy on alkali modified alumina support; while the latter uses and CrOx on alumina catalysts [3–6]. However, due to toxicity and environmental hazard of the latter, alternative metal oxide catalysts are being actively researched [6,7]. While many metal oxides have been studied, those based on Ga oxide appear to be closest to commercialization. BP-UOP’s Cyclar process [8], first reported the dehydrogenation activity of gallium supported on ZSM-5 for conversion of propane and butanes to benzene, toluene and xylenes [9–20]. In the bifunctional catalyst, the Ga catalyst converts alkanes to olefins, which subsequently form aromatics on Bronsted acid sites [10,14,19–27]. For Ga catalysts with few acid sites, however, olefins are the main products [20,28–32]. While Ga on alumina is active, addition of small amounts of Pt, e.g., 0.1%, to Ga (3 wt%) on γ-Al2O3 gives a highly active and stable catalyst [33–35]. In the present study, we have prepared 3–15 wt% Ga PDH catalysts where the majority of Ga is present as isolated Ga+3 ions with 4 Ga-O bonds stabilize by the γ-Al2O3 support. The nature of the Ga coordination is characterized by XAS and atomic resolution STEM. For PDH, the propylene selectivity decreases with increasing conversion and is dependent on the propane partial pressure. In addition to the expected PDH reaction product propylene, secondary reactions of propylene form by-products of methane, ethane and ethylene, and C4 hydrocarbons, which lowers the selectivity. Although the propylene selectivity is higher on Ga/SiO2 than that on alumina, secondary reactions of propylene also occur on the former. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis The Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Ga loadings (3, 6, 9, 12, and 15%) were synthesized by incipient wetness impregnation (IWI). To prepare 3% Ga/γ-Al2O3, for example, 2.2 g of Ga(NO3)3·xH2O (Sigma-Aldrich) was dissolved in 8.0 mL deionized water. The solution was then added dropwise to 20.0 g of Alumina (Sasol CATALOX SBA-200; 0.5 cc/g, pore size = 40–100 Å, surface area = 200 m2/g). The mixture was dried overnight at 110 °C and then calcined for 3 h in air at 550 °C. 3% Ga/SiO2 was synthesized using the incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) method. 1.5 g of Ga (NO3)3xH2O and 1.5 g of citric acid (Sigma Aldrich) were dissolved in DI 7.5 mL water and added dropwise to 10 g of Davisil silica grade 636 (0.75 cc/g, pore size = 60 Å, surface area = 480 m2/g). The catalyst was dried at 125 °C overnight and subsequently calcined at 550 °C for 3 h. 2.2 Catalyst evaluations Propane dehydrogenation over 3% Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalysts was carried out in a fixed-bed quartz reactor (inner diameter = 10.5 mm) [36]. The reactor was heated using an electrical furnace (Applied Test System Series 3210), and the temperature of the catalyst bed was measured using a K-type thermocouple positioned in the middle of the catalyst bed. The 3% Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was dried at 550 °C in N2 at 100 mL/min for 1 hr. At the reaction temperature, the propane flow rate was adjusted by a mass flow controller (Parker Porter, CM400). The catalysts were initially screened at 6 kPa to determine the Turn Over Rate (TOR) and product selectivity. The 15% Ga/γ-Al2O3 was evaluated in more detail at 134 kPa propane. The catalyst mass, e.g., 0.25–1.0 g, and flow rates, 25–100 ccm, were varied to obtain propane conversions from 5 to 35%. Fresh catalyst was tested at each conversion. Other Ga loadings on alumina (6, 9, 12, and 15%) and 3% Ga/SiO2 were evaluated using the same approach. Reaction products were determined by an online gas chromatograph (GC) (Agilent 7890A) equipped with a Restek Rt-Alumina Bond/Na2SO4 GC column (30 m in length, 0.32 mm ID, and 0.5 m film thickness) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The lines from the reactor to the GC were insulated by heat tape (Omega) up 150 °C. Data points were collected every 15 min for PDH. The reaction products included H2, methane, ethane, ethylene, propylene, and higher molecular weight C4 and C5 hydrocarbons. Catalytic performance for propylene conversion was determined in the same fixed-bed reactor at 550 °C and 4–40 kPa (pressure gauge) propylene/balance N2 for the (3, 12, and 15%) Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The amounts of catalyst and flow rates were varied to obtain propylene conversions from 5 to 15%. 2.3 Magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS-NMR) spectroscopy MAS-NMR data were collected through the Purdue Interdepartmental NMR facility. The spectrometer is a Chemagnetics CMX-400 with a wide-bore magnet and a Chemagnetics 5 mm H-X-Y triple-resonance MAS probe. For the 27Al spectra, the parameters were as follows: 1-pulse acquisition with no 1H decoupling, pulse width of 2.3us (nominal P90 of 27Al using a solution-state sample of 7 us), relaxation delay of 0.5 s, and an acquisition time of 25.6 ms. Sample rotation rate was 6 KHz and 1 k scans were typically acquired. Data were processed using a left-shift of two data points, exponential multiplication with a line-broadening of 100 Hz and one zero-fill. Each peak was integrated relative to the baseline in order to determine relative occupancy. Attempts to obtain Ga MAS NMR spectra were unsuccessful. 2.4 Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) Samples were dispersed in ethanol and inserted on a holey carbon grid in a JEOL NeoARM 200CF scanning transmission electron microscope equipped with a spherical aberration corrector. Images were recorded in annular dark field (ADF) mode as well as in annular bright field mode (ABF). 2.5 X-ray diffraction (XRD) X-ray diffraction data were collected using a Rigaku SmartLab X-ray Diffractometer using a Cu-target Kα source (λ = 1.54056 Å) in air. Data was collected scanning at 1°/min in steps of 0.004° from 25° to 50° in 2θ. 2.6 X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) XAS experiments were performed at the MR-CAT 10-BM beamline at the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory. The catalyst materials were scanned at the Ga K edge (10.367 keV) for all of the Ga/Al2O3 samples. Samples were pressed into a six-sample holder in a controlled atmosphere in situ cell. The samples were scanned as-synthesized in air, during high temperature (550 °C) treatment in 20% O2, and 3% C3H8 (all in balance He), and after the treatment by cooling to room temperature and scanning in He. A Zn foil (9659 eV) was scanned simultaneously with the sample for energy calibration. The X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) were analyzed using WinXAS v.3.1 software [37]. Ga2O3 and gallium (III) acetylacetonate (both Sigma Aldrich) were scanned as standards. All samples were fit using an experimentally generated scattering path from gallium (III) acetylacetonate. An EXAFS fit was performed on the k2-weighted, Fourier-transform of the sample in R-space as well as on the back-Fourier-transformed (first shell isolated) q-space. 2.7 Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) The amounts of coke for the propane and propylene reactions were determined by Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) at two different times: 15 min and also 4 h after the start of the reaction. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were performed on a TA Instruments SDT Q600 thermogravimetric analyzer and differential scanning calorimeter (TGA-DSC) by heating 0.02 g of 15% Ga/γ-Al2O3 in dry air (UHP, 99.999%, Indiana Oxygen) to 800 °C. The coke weight % of catalyst is calculated with Eq (1). (1) C o k e w t % = 1 - initial m a s s final m a s s ∗ 100 3 Results 3.1 Catalyst characterization The alumina in this study was a high-purity γ-Al2O3 with a BET surface area of 200 m2/g. In addition, 27Al MAS-NMR were obtained to determine the relative occupancy of tetrahedral and octahedral Al. The normalized MAS NMR spectra for both γ-Al2O3 and the catalyst with the highest Ga loading (15% Ga/γ-Al2O3) are depicted in Figure S1. The peaks observed at −78 ppm and −9 ppm correspond to tetrahedral (Td) and octahedral (Oh) coordination, respectively. The integrated peak area for each sample is summarized in Table S1. In all samples, the Al coordination is approximately 23% Td and 77% Oh which is consistent with previous MAS-NMR studies conducted for γ-Al2O3 [38]. XRD spectra of γ-Al2O3 and Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalysts (Figure S2) show four broad peaks at approximately 32°, 38°, 40°, and 46° 2θ, which closely resemble those previously reported for mixed oxides of γ-Ga2O3 and γ-Al2O3 [39]. Peaks attributed to bulk Ga2O3 were absent in all spectra. With increasing Ga loading, peaks at 32° and 38° 2θ shift to lower 2θ and increase in intensity, while peaks at 40° and 46° 2θ remain unchanged. To better quantify the changes in the XRD with increasing Ga loading, the XRD spectrum of γ-Al2O3 was subtracted from the spectrum of each Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, as shown in Figure S3. For the XRD peaks at 32° and 38° 2θ, there is a good correlation (R = 0.998 and R = 0.996 respectively) between the increase in peak intensity and the Ga weight loading, Figure S4. The shift and intensity change in the peaks at 32 and 38° 2θ suggests that Ga is substituted into the γ-Al2O3. However, since there are no changes in the XRD peaks at 40 and 46° 2θ, this suggests that the Ga ions are not uniformly distributed into the alumina, i.e., Ga is not forming a solid solution with alumina. The Ga K-edge X-ray absorption near edge spectra (XANES) and X-ray absorption fine spectra (EXAFS) were obtained on the Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalysts to determine the oxidation state and local coordination geometry, such as the number of Ga-O bonds and bond distance. The XANES energy is defined as the inflection point of the leading edge. The XANES energy of Td Ga occurs at lower energy than Oh Ga ions. For example, the XANES energy of Ga(AcAc)3, i.e., octahedral (Oh) Ga, occurs at 10.3768 keV, see Fig. 1 a (Black) and Table S2. The XANES energy of Ga2O3, which has 50% tetrahedral (Td) and 50% Oh coordination, is 10.3740 keV, and is due to the lower energy of the Td coordinated Ga ions. The XANES spectra of the 3, 6, 9, 12 and 15% Ga/ γ-Al2O3 catalysts (Red) are identical in shape and XANES energy, 10.3747 keV, are consistent with Td coordinated Ga+3 ions and indicate that the structure of all Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are the same, see Table S2. The XANES energy of 3% Ga/SiO2 is 10.3746 keV, Table S2, and is also consistent with Td coordination. The k2-weighted EXAFS magnitudes of 3% Ga/γ-Al2O3 (Red), 3% Ga/SiO2 (Blue) and the Ga(AcAc)3 (Black) reference are shown in Fig. 1b. The first shell Ga-O scattering peak at approximately 1.9 Å (phase uncorrected distance) in Ga(AcAc)3, is larger and shifted to higher R compared to the Ga-O peaks in the Ga/alumina and Ga/silica catalysts. The first shell EXAFS fit of Ga(AcAc)3 gives 6 Ga-O bonds at 1.95 Å; while, there are 4 Ga-O bonds at 1.84 Å in the Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (Table S2). Additionally, the EXAFS of the 3% Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibits a small, higher-shell peak due to Ga-(O)-Al scattering, with 4 Ga-(O)-Al neighbors at 3.23 Å. Attempts to fit the higher shell fit with Ga-O-Ga scattering gave poor fits. Similar results were obtained for all Ga/alumina catalysts, as shown in Table S2. The spectra were identical after treatment in propane at propane dehydrogenation conditions of 550 °C. EXAFS fits of the 3% Ga/SiO2 (Fig. 1b, Blue) also gave 4 Ga-O bonds at 1.84 Å similar to previously reported results [40]. For Ga/SiO2, there is a smaller higher shell peak which was fit with 2 Ga-(O)-Si bonds at 3.21 Å. Atomic-resolution STEM images were obtained for the as synthesized 15% Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, Fig. 2 a and 2b. The lattice images from the γ-Al2O3 are seen in both figures. In addition, individual bright spots (circled in yellow) are consistent with isolated Ga atoms. There are no indications of Ga oxide clusters, despite the high Ga loading suggesting that the Ga ions are atomically dispersed. 3.2 Catalyst performance 3.2.1 Propane dehydrogenation Each of the Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Ga loadings (3, 6, 9, 12, and 15 wt%) was evaluated for propane dehydrogenation (PDH) at a propane partial pressure of 6 kP and 550 °C to determine difference in selectivity and rate with Ga loading. The influence of heat and mass transfer limitations was evaluated, and the calculations are shown in the SI. The Thiele modulus was estimated to be about 0.05 giving an effectiveness factor of 1.0, and the Mears and Anderson criteria was ca. 10−7 indicating the absence of heat and mass transfer effects for the catalyst evaluations. Table 1 gives the PDH product selectivity at two different conversions by changing the space velocity and the TOR rates at differential conversion for the Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The propylene selectivity is higher at low conversion and decreases at higher conversion. Within the error of the measurements, the propane conversion rates per Ga, i.e., the turnover rate (TOR), are the same, 1.2×10−3 mol C3H8/mole-Ga-s−1, for each Ga loading from 3 to 15%. At low conversions of less than about 10%, the propylene selectivity is near 95% but decreases to about 85% at 25–30% conversion. The by-products include methane and C2s (ethane and ethylene), but there are also small amounts of C4 and C5 products. The selectivity to higher molecular weight products increases with increasing conversion. The product selectivity of each catalyst was determined from about 5–35% propane conversion at 6 and 134 kPa and are shown in Fig. 3 . The propylene selectivity at 6 kPa decreases linearly with increasing propane conversion. At about 35% propane conversion, for example, the propylene selectivity is near 80%. In addition, the selectivity is independent of the Ga loading suggesting that the structure of the active site in each catalyst is identical. The by-product selectivity for methane, C2s (ethane and ethylene), and total C4 selectivities are shown in Fig. 3b-3d for each Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The selectivity of each by-product increases with increasing conversion, and all catalysts have identical selectivities. Iso-butylene is the major C4 hydrocarbon (>60%). The C2 hydrocarbons were >70 % ethylene. The selectivity to methane is about 3%. The product selectivity at each conversion and for each catalyst is given in Tables S3-S7. The propylene and by-product selectivities at 134 kPa propane partial pressure are also shown in Fig. 3. As observed at lower pressure the propylene selectivity decreases with increasing conversion, however, is significantly lower at higher partial pressure. The by-product selectivities of methane, C2s (ethane and ethylene), and total C4 hydrocarbon selectivities increase linearly with increasing propane conversion, but are much higher at higher propane partial pressure. The complete product selectivities at each conversion are given in Table S8. The PDH deactivation at 134 kPa and 550 °C, i.e., propane conversion verses time, for the 15% Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is shown in Fig. 4 . The initial conversion drops from about 33% to 25% during the first hour and then declines more slowly at longer time. The amount of coke on the catalyst was also determined for PDH after 15 min and 4 h. In separate tests, the weight loss due to coke (Eq. (1) in section 2.7) was determined by temperature programmed oxidation up to 800 °C and is reported in Table 2 . Nearly 7% coke was formed after 15 min; while, an additional 3% coke is formed in about 4 h. The product selectivity for the coked catalyst were obtained after 1 h on stream for the 15% Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalyst and are summarized in Table S9. As shown in Figure S5, the selectivities of the fresh and coked catalysts are identical suggesting that carbon is primarily deposited on alumina with minimal impact on the remaining active gallium sites. To compare the performance of the (3–15)% Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with that of 3% Ga/SiO2, the latter was also tested under the same reaction conditions used for Ga/γ-Al2O3, e.g., 550 °C, 6 kPa. The propylene selectivity with increasing propane conversion is shown Fig. 5 a along with the selectivity of 15% Ga/γ-Al2O3. The by-product selectivities with increasing conversion are shown in Fig. 5b. As the propane conversion increases, the propylene selectivity linearly decreases (Fig. 5a). At a propane conversion close to 35%, propylene selectivity is 94%, which is significantly higher than that for Ga/γ-Al2O3, which is about 81%. The selectivity of methane, C2s, and C4s are reported in Fig. 5b for the 3% Ga/SiO2 catalyst. The selectivity of by-products increases with increasing propane conversion. Almost 40% of C4s products are isobutylene, and 80% of C2s products are ethylene. The TOR of 3% Ga/SiO2 in the PDH process is 4.6×10−4, approximately 2.5 times lower than that for Ga/γ-Al2O3. The product selectivities of Ga/SiO2 at each conversion are given in Table S10. 3.2.2 Propylene conversion The PDH selectivity for methane, C2s, C4 and C5 hydrocarbons extrapolated to zero conversion are near zero percent and suggest that these light gas products are formed by secondary reactions of the primary product propylene, see Figs. 3 and 5. Thus, the reaction of propylene at approximately the same concentrations and temperature as that for PDH was investigated. Since the propylene partial pressure is lower than that of propane due to the partial conversion, initially the 3% and 12% Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were evaluated at a propylene partial pressure of ca. 4 kPa. Fig. 6 shows the propylene reaction product selectivities with increasing conversion up to about 10% for the 12% Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. In Fig. 6a, C4 and C2 hydrocarbons were the major products. The total C4 selectivity at low conversion was about 45% but decreased slightly with increasing propylene conversion. The C2 hydrocarbons selectivity was about 25–30% and were > 95% ethylene. Although the propylene reaction was conducted without added H2, 15% propane was also formed. The methane and C5 selectivities each were about 5%. Fig. 6b shows the C4 product distribution with increasing propylene conversion. The most abundant product is iso-butylene, which is about 60% of C4 products. As the propylene conversion increases to 10 %, the iso-butylene and 1,3-butadiene selectivities decrease slightly, while the other C4 products increase. The selectivities for 3% Ga/γ-Al2O3 are very similar to those for the 12% Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The selectivity of all products for the 3% and 12% Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are given in Tables S11, and S12, respectively. Finally, the propylene TOR was 3.4×10−4 mol C3H6/mole-Ga s−1, which is about 3.5 times lower than the TOR for PDH at 550 °C. The reaction products for propylene conversion at a higher partial pressure of 40 kPa were also determined for the 15% Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Table S13 gives the product selectivities from about 20–40% conversion. Methane, propane, C2s, and C4s were the major products; however, at higher partial pressure, the propane selectivity was ca. 45% and is significantly higher than that at lower partial pressure, ca. 15%. At higher partial pressure, the selectivity to C2s and C4s are lower, 17 and 17%, than that at 4 kPa, 25 and 45% respectively. The methane selectivity is significantly higher than at low pressure, 15 and 5%, respectively; while the C5s selectivity is lower at high partial pressure, about 2–3%. The loss in propylene conversion with time is shown in Fig. 7 . The initial deactivation rate is higher and decreases at longer times on stream, similar to PDH deactivation, Fig. 4. In separate tests, the amount of coke on the catalyst was also determined for propylene conversion after 15 min and 4 h. The weight loss of coke is also reported in Table 2. Similar to PDH, propylene conversion gave higher coking rates at 15 min, ca. 10%, while at 4 h the amount of coke was 15%. The coking rate of propylene was about 30% higher than for PDH. Since there is little propylene at the reactor inlet during the initial stages of PDH, this may account for the lower amounts of coke for this reaction. As shown in Fig. 5, the product selectivity for PDH for 3% Ga/SiO2 extrapolated to zero conversion indicates that propylene is near 100% and all light gases are close to 0% similar to what was observed for Ga/γ-Al2O3. Again, this suggests that methane, C2s, C4s and C5s are secondary products formed by reaction of propylene. Thus, the propylene conversion rate and product selectivities were also determined at the PDH reaction conditions, e.g., temperature and approximately 4 kPa propylene partial pressure. As shown in Fig. 8 a, the major products include C2s, propane, and C4s. Almost 70% of C2 products are ethylene. Again, despite the absence of H2 in the feed, the reaction of propylene produces about 30% propane. Fig. 8b shows the distribution of C4s products. The major C4s products are iso-butylene and 1,3-butadiene. The selectivity of each product at each conversion is given in Table S14. Finally, the 3% Ga/SiO2 TOR is 1.1×10−4, which is approximately 4 times lower than that for PDH. 4 Discussion Numerous publications confirm Ga's effectiveness for propane dehydrogenation (PDH), with both bulk oxide and supported catalysts. Various structures of the active Ga have been proposed in zeolites, such as Ga+3, Ga+, [GaO]+, [Ga2O2]2+, [GaH2]+, [GaH]2+, [GaOH]+, [HGaOH]+, Ga+–H+ cation pairs, and Ga2O3 clusters [10,13,19,32,41–47]. Under high-temperature H2 conditions, isolated Ga+3 in zeolites [13] and Ga/SiO2 exhibit similar XANES spectra [32] suggesting the presence of gallium hydride species. Solid solutions of Ga/γ-Al2O3 [34,35] with tetrahedral and octahedral Ga coordination have demonstrated PDH activity. At lower Ga loadings, the majority of Ga sites have Td coordination by Ga MAS NMR; while EXAFS indicates there are 4 Ga-O bonds at 1.84 Å. These are suggested to be the active catalytic structure. The EXAFS of our supported Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are very similar to that for the Ga2O3-Al2O3 solid solutions with a similar coordination geometry, i.e., 4 Ga-O at 1.84 Å with 4 Ga-O-Al higher shell bonds. Isolated Ga ions were confirmed for the 15% Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalyst by atomic resolution STEM, Fig. 2, where individual Ga ions are observed with no visible Ga oxide clusters. The TORs calculated based on the total number of Ga atoms is within the experimental errors also identical. For any highly propylene-selective PDH catalyst, it is essential to minimize the formation of light gas by-products. Thus, it is necessary to understand the reaction pathway that leads to these unwanted by-products. For Pt and Pt alloy catalysts, the reaction mechanism for propylene and light gas formation has been widely studied by Density Functional theory [6,48–55]. There is general agreement that the initial step in the reaction network involves propane adsorption followed dissociation of one C–H to form 1-propyl (*CH2CH2CH3) or 2-propyl (CH3*CHCH3) and a H* surface intermediate. Subsequent β-hydrogen abstraction of the adsorbed intermediate leads to formation of the adsorbed hydrocarbon with a double bond. Desorption from the surface gives the olefin product. However, the adsorbed double bonded intermediate can also undergo further loss of additional hydrogen to form deeply dehydrogenated intermediates. Hydrogenolysis, or breaking of a C–C bond, is thought to occur form these deeply dehydrogenated intermediates. Hydrogenation of the smaller surface species leads to methane and ethylene in equal molar amounts, for example. Based on this mechanism propylene, methane and ethylene are primary products resulting from reactions of the initial, surface propyl intermediates. The reaction pathway is given in Scheme 1 (Top). DFT studies have also been conducted for the propane dehydrogenation reaction mechanism with ionic and oxide catalysts [6,56–61]. There is general agreement that the initial reaction is a heterogeneous dissociation of an initial C–H bond transferring a proton to the support M-O to form and hydroxyl and M-alkyl carbanion. The M-alkyl subsequently undergoes a β-H (i.e., hydride) elimination forming a M-H surface intermediate and the olefin product. Recombination of the M-H and acidic, support O–H gives H2 [6,56–61]. While there is agreement for the mechanistic steps for alkane dehydrogenation, the mechanistic steps for formation of light gases is less well understood. The light gas products have been suggested to occur by parallel reactions of the initially formed M-alkyl intermediate similar to the Top pathway in Scheme 1 [57–61]. Although the product selectivities at higher conversions are consistent with those reported in the literature [33], extrapolation to zero percent propane conversion for Ga/γ-Al2O3 and Ga/SiO2 (Figures S6 and S8) indicates that the propylene selectivity is near 100% and light gas formation is very low indicating the latter are secondary products of the initially formed propylene, Scheme 1 (Bottom). This is confirmed by reaction of propylene, which gives the same light gas products observed for propane dehydrogenation. While the reaction of propylene produces the expected methane and C2 light gas products, for Ga/γ-Al2O3 the selectivity to C2s is significantly higher than that due to propane hydrogenolysis alone, see Table 3 and Figure S7. As observed in Table 3, methane is a relatively minor by-product; while the major light gases are propane, butenes and pentenes, which are unexpected products from hydrogenolysis of alkyl reaction intermediates. For example, propane is formed even in the absence of H2; thus, the reaction of propylene undergoes significant H-transfer reactions. In addition, for Ga/γ-Al2O3, the weight ratio of ethylene to butenes (23:49) is close to a 1:1 molar ratio, perhaps, suggesting a disproportionation reaction of propylene, wherein 2 propylene molecules give rise to 1 ethylene and 1 butene. Similar products were recently reported for propylene conversion on γ-Al2O3 at 260 °C and 1.5 atm [62]. Pentenes may result from the oligomerization of propylene with ethylene [40]. If the light gas products occur by an independent pathway from propane dehydrogenation, the selectivity to these products should also be dependent on the process conditions, for example, the propylene partial pressure. At higher partial pressures, propane dehydrogenation gives the same reaction products, e.g., propylene and light gases, Fig. 3 and Tables S3-S8; however, at the same conversion the propylene selectivity is significantly lower and the light gas by-products are higher (Fig. 3). This decrease in propylene selectivity can be attributed to the higher selectivities for light gas by-products (Fig. 3b-3d). At the same conversion but higher propane partial pressures, the partial pressure of propylene is higher, thus the rate of secondary reactions is higher, i.e., higher selectivity to light gas products. All of these results, suggest that mechanism and reaction pathway for light gas formation differ from those on noble metal catalysts. We propose that propylene is the major primary product of propane dehydrogenation by Ga/γ-Al2O3, which undergoes a series of secondary reactions producing methane, ethylene, butenes and pentenes. While the reaction products have been identified and possible reactions steps have been suggested, the reaction intermediates and mechanism for these products has not yet been determined. 5 Conclusion Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with 3–15% by weight of Ga were synthesized using the IWI method and calcination at 550C. Characterizations, by XRD, STEM, and XAS indicate that at all loadings the majority of Ga is present as isolated, four coordinate Ga+3 ions are bonded to γ-Al2O3. In addition, the PDH TOR rates and product selectivities of all Ga/γ-Al2O3 were identical. The PDH propylene selectivity decreases with increasing conversion and was also dependent on the propane partial pressure. The PDH by-products included methane, ethane and unexpectedly butenes and pentenes. Extrapolation of the PDH products to zero propane conversion indicates that the intrinsic propylene selectivity is near 100%, i.e., is a primary product. The near zero selectivity of all light gases extrapolated to zero propane conversion, however, indicates these are secondary reactions. Consistent with this conclusion, the reaction of propylene on Ga/γ-Al2O3 at PDH conditions gives primary products of methane, ethylene, propane, butenes and pentenes. Thus, although the PDH intrinsic propylene selectivity is very high, these secondary reactions of the initial product give lower selectivity at higher conversions and higher propane partial pressure. A 3% Ga/SiO2 was also prepared and has a very similar structure to that of Ga/γ-Al2O3, i.e., isolated, four coordinate Ga+3 ions bonded to the silica support. Although, the PDH propylene selectivity of the former was higher than that of the latter, the same by-products were formed, including butenes and pentenes. Similar to the Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, extrapolation of the selectivity to zero propane conversion indicate that propylene is a primary product with a high intrinsic selectivity near 100%. Likewise, the selectivity of the light gases extrapolated to zero conversion indicate these are secondary products, which was confirmed by the direct reaction of propylene. The differences in the rates and selectivities for PDH and propylene conversion of Ga/γ-Al2O3 and Ga/SiO2 also suggests that that the catalytic performance is dependent on the support type. coredata.dc:description: Supported Ga catalysts have been widely studied for propane dehydrogenation (PDH). In this study, Ga/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were evaluated for PDH. The propylene selectivity decreased with increasing propane conversion. It is generally thought that propylene and light gas by-products occur from chemisorbed propane and are, therefore, primary products. By extrapolating the product selectivities to zero per cent propane conversion, the initial propylene selectivity was near 100% and is a primary product. The light gas selectivities, however, are near 0% indicating that these are secondary products. The direct reaction of propylene produced the same light gas products, e.g., methane, ethylene, propane, butenes and pentenes, observed for PDH and confirmed that these occur by an independent reaction of propylene. Thus, while the intrinsic PDH propylene selectivity is high, these secondary propylene reactions lower the selectivity, especially, at higher conversions and higher partial pressures.
coredata.dc:title: Secondary reactions of propylene on Ga/γ-Al2O3 propane dehydrogenation catalysts

dcterms:subject.$: Propylene secondary reactions during propane dehydrogenation
